unnormalised: **Vendor Audits Tighten Grip on Quality Control in Indian Manufacturing**
normalised: vendor audits tighten grip on quality control in indian manufacturing

unnormalised: MUMBAI – Indian manufacturers are increasingly leveraging stringent vendor audits to ensure quality and compliance across their supply chains, industry experts noted at the recent CII Supply Chain Conclave in Mumbai.
normalised: mumbai – indian manufacturers are increasingly leveraging stringent vendor audits to ensure quality and compliance across their supply chains, industry experts noted at the recent C I I supply chain conclave in mumbai.

unnormalised: “In today's competitive landscape, vendor audits are no longer optional; they are critical for maintaining brand reputation and ensuring customer satisfaction,” stated Mr. Rajesh Sharma, CEO of Bharat Engineering.
normalised: “in today's competitive landscape, vendor audits are no longer optional; they are critical for maintaining brand reputation and ensuring customer satisfaction,” stated mister rajesh sharma, C E O of Bharat Engineering.

unnormalised: The audits are encompassing a wide range of factors, including adherence to labour laws, environmental regulations, and quality standards like ISO 9001. Special focus is being given to vendors supplying ingredients for the food processing sector ahead of the Onam festival, when demand for traditional dishes like biryani surges.
normalised: the audits are encompassing a wide range of factors, including adherence to labor laws, environmental regulations, and quality standards like I S O nine thousand and one. special focus is being given to vendors supplying ingredients for the food processing sector ahead of the Onam festival, when demand for traditional dishes like biryani surges.

unnormalised: Many companies are employing independent auditors, like those certified by the Quality Council of India, for unbiased assessments. Failure to meet audit benchmarks can lead to contract termination, impacting vendors reliant on large contracts.
normalised: many companies are employing independent auditors, like those certified by the Quality Council of India, for unbiased assessments. failure to meet audit benchmarks can lead to contract termination, impacting vendors reliant on large contracts.

unnormalised: "We recently terminated a contract with a vendor in Tamil Nadu after repeated audit failures concerning safety protocols. Rs. 5 Lakhs in penalties were also levied," confirmed Ms. Priya Menon, Supply Chain Head at Hindustan Foods. The move underscores the seriousness with which Indian manufacturers are now approaching vendor oversight. These audits are covering production facilities located in even remote areas - sometimes requiring travel of 1500 km to reach them.
